content.webTitle: Newcastle’s Steve McClaren delighted with side despite defeat to Watford

fields.headline: Newcastle’s Steve McClaren delighted with side despite defeat to Watford
fields.bodyText: The contrasting demeanours of the two managers after this game was a sight to behold as one humbly admitted his team were too predictable and had to change, while the other was positively glowing with appreciation for the latest in a string of impressive performances. The surprise was the victorious manager of the top-10 side was relatively downcast, while the coach of the relegation-haunted losers was swelling with pride. “You can only win games if you perform and we’ve got to keep performing like that,” Steve McClaren said, beaming. “You have to play well enough to give yourself a chance and we’re playing well enough in every game. We have to keep doing what we’re doing.” Given Newcastle have won one of their past eight games and had only two shots on target in this one, what they are doing does not seem to be particularly impressive. “We’ve performed very well but we need to follow that up and we’ve failed to do that,” McClaren said. “Last week we took the opportunity against West Ham. This was a very good opportunity, we should have taken it, we didn’t. We’re a team who’s competing, playing good football, playing well, deserving more from the performances, but not getting it.” Given that Watford had lost their four previous games Quique Sánchez Flores could not even attempt a similar argument, so in a bewildering atypical move this advocate of tactical, selectorial and, for that matter, sartorial consistency had introduced his team to a new formation only 24 hours before the kick-off. Watford abandoned their favoured 4-4-1-1 for the first time this season as Sánchez Flores sacrificed wide midfielders to counter Newcastle’s threat in the centre. “When I analysed Newcastle with Shelvey, he makes the other big players, good players, play well – really well,” Sánchez Flores said. “So for us it was very important to keep watching Shelvey. Also to attack three defenders we had to think about other things. We were attacking always with Ighalo, with Deeney. We are very predictable. So we needed to think a little bit different. If something is working I don’t like to mix. I don’t like to confuse the players changing the system every single week. I believe a lot in the way we were playing until now but sometimes it is necessary to change.” In further head-scratching analysis, Sánchez Flores said Watford “had the ball more in the first half and could play well”, while McClaren insisted his side “controlled the game in the first half and dominated”. Sánchez Flores was pleased with the way his side silenced Shelvey, while McClaren thought the player controlled the game. In truth Shelvey’s position at the base of a midfield three made it difficult for him to influence proceedings in key areas, even if it was his corner Jamaal Lascelles headed in with 19 minutes to play. The argument over which side had the better of the first half is moot, since the game was decided at the start of the second. The interplay between Troy Deeney and Odion Ighalo may have become predictable but Newcastle notably failed to anticipate it seconds after the restart as the Nigerian ran on to his partner’s through ball to put the home side ahead, while both were also involved in the build-up to Craig Cathcart’s volleyed second. It was Watford’s third win against Newcastle this season, all by a single goal. “I wouldn’t like to play them every week, because they have a very good team,” Sánchez Flores said. “We deserve the victory but they have very good players. We won against an amazing team.” Finally, something on which he and McClaren agreed. Man of the match José Manuel Jurado (Watford)
